bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jose R. Andreu, February 21, 1952

div1.p: Hench thanks Andreu for the Order of Finlay, and asks for a copy of Andreu's speech. He is delighted to know that there is a plan to memorialize Camp Lazear, and hopes that he will be able to attend the ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jose R. Andreu, February 21, 1952
div1.opener:
February 21, 1952
Dr. Jose R. Andreu
Ministerio de Salubridad y Asistencia Social
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Andreu:
div1.p:
Mrs. Hench and I had a rough crossing on the boat from Havana to Miami but
thanks to dramamine we weathered the storm; however on the way home I
caught a severe cold from which I am just recovering.

I wish to thank you again, Doctor Andreu, most sincerely for the great dis-
tinction which you and your colleagues of the Cuban Government conferred
upon me in giving me the Condecoracion de la Order del Merito Nacional
“Carlos Finlay.” This was a very pleasant surprise and a very delightful
occasion for Mrs. Hench and me.

I would appreciate it greatly if you would send to me a copy of your speech.
Although it is in Spanish, I can readily have it translated here. I believe
Mario LeRoy gave it in English but unfortunately I do not have his address.

I have enjoyed greatly the delightful friendships which I have made through
the years with so many of your countrymen. This has given me great pleasure
and because of it Mrs. Hench and I have visited Havana every two or three
years. We hope to continue this happy relationship.

I am delighted indeed to know that your government and your department in
particular, is planning to memorialize Camp Lazear. It will be a great oc-
casion when the little camp is dedicated and I hope indeed to be notified so
that I can some if at all possible. I know very well that your own efforts
in regard to this project have been of the greatest importance and I know
that you have had it in your heart for many years.

I am going to Washington today for a few days and while there I am going to
tell my various friends in the Medical Department of the Army of your plans.
Not only will the Surgeon General be delighted to hear of them, but in
particular Generals Truby and Reed and Mr. William Houston Lazear (the
martyr Doctor Lazear's son) will be delighted to hear of them.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
